@/color-fade.description: `val` over the range maps to brightness the color.

BJNL-PUXE.description: Set to true if the 2nd color is red
BJNL-PUXE.label: 2-red

Sk5NWwLX4.description: Set to true if the 1st color is blue
Sk5NWwLX4.label: 1-blue

SyWN8WDUQ4.description: Set to true if the 2nd color is blue
SyWN8WDUQ4.label: 2-blue

r1O7bvLQV.description: Set to true if the 1st color is green
r1O7bvLQV.label: 1-green

r1l4IZw8QV.description: Set to true if the 2nd color is green
r1l4IZw8QV.label: 2-green

rkiG-vIXN.description: Set to true if the 1st color is red
rkiG-vIXN.label: 1-red

@/color-order.description:
Use  example-rgb-revelation to discover the color-order.
Set one of the 1-x's to true.
Set one of  the 2-x's to true.
The third is deduced.

@/defer(adafruitneopixel).description: Allows to create feedback loops. Repeats a change of the input on the output right after the current transaction will complete.

@/equal(adafruitneopixel).description: Outputs true if `IN1` = `IN2`, and false otherwise

r1WBAvEkV.description:
neopixels can be painfully bright.
pick a reasonable number.
r1WBAvEkV.label: brightness

BkBqgfDiQ4.content:
Hook up according to the colors that showed on the first trial:
Set one of the 1-x's to true. Set one of the 2-x's to true. 
The third is deduced.

BknKSD4yE.content:
Helps you figure out the correct RGB-order setting ("color-order" node).
By showing 3 colors, in order, on the first 3 pixels.
Follow instructions below.

Byt1VDsXE.content:
At least 3 pixels, more is OK, but has no effect.
The first pixel (0) is nearest the Arduino

HJVqeGPomN.content: You chould use the actual hex value if you know it. e.g. for GRWB, etc.

S1zeNzXl4.content: delay turns them off for a moment

Skkv_DEy4.content: You should adjust 'p', the pin to the NeoPixel Data-In

rJvlCgTPi.content:
First, set the Pin that the neopixel is on.
It's that "val" node just below, that is hooked to 'p'.
On my CircuitPlayGround Express, I used pin 8.
On several of the M0 and M4's from Adafruit, you probably want the special pin 5

HyVVAlTDi.content:
Start with "True" hooked to "color-order" 1-red, and 2-green.
Then upload.
The first 3 pixels will show 3 colors.
Record the colors that actually show. Mine showed as green-red-blue.
Hook "True" to the first color that showed (for me, that's 1-green),
and also hook "True" to the second color that showed (for me, that's 2-red).
Mine shows as Green Red Blue, so 1-green, 2-red.
Upload with that, should show as Red Green Blue when you get it right.

@/example-rgb-revelation.description: Helps you decode the right RGB code to use (e.g. GRB, etc), by lighting up 3 colors. Clone this node, and follow the instructions.

rJ9xVl_E1E.description:
neopixels can be painfully bright.
pick a reasonable number.

BkVPTLoQN.content:
You could adjust 'n' the number of pixels if >1, but we only use the first one here.
"pixel" 0 is nearest the Arduino

H1r-lNxOVJE.content:
Helps you figure out the correct RGB-order setting ("color-order" node).
By showing 3 colors, in order, on the first pixel only (then pauses off).
Like the 3 pixel revelation, but this only requires 1 pixel.
This should do white as well, but it doesn't yet.
It ignores pixels past the first, so they might have any/no color when this runs.

SJMN1zQlV.content: You could make a patch for these 3. And then reuse it, but I can't in an example

rk7MgwoXN.content:
You chould use the actual hex value if you know it. e.g. for GRWB, etc.
See the "#define NEO_..." in
https://github.com/adafruit/Adafruit_NeoPixel/blob/master/Adafruit_NeoPixel.h
Around line 90

ryOblNgdV1N.content: You should adjust 'p', the pin to the NeoPixel Data-In

ryPWlExdNJ4.content:
Hook up according to the colors that showed on the first trial:
Set one of the 1-x's to true. Set one of the 2-x's to true. 
The third is deduced.

HkQ1Be6wj.content:
First, set the Pin that the neopixel is on.
It's that "val" node just below, that is hooked to 'p'.
On my CircuitPlayGround Express, I used pin 8.
On several of the M0 and M4's from Adafruit, you probably want the special pin 5

Sy8YrxTwi.content:
Start with "True" hooked to "color-order" 1-red, and 2-green.
Then upload.
Your first neopixel will  go through 3 colors, and then off for a moment.
Record the colors that actually show. Mine showed as green-red-blue.
Hook "True" to the first color that showed (for me, that's 1-green),
and also hook "True" to the second color that showed (for me, that's 2-red).
Mine shows as Green Red Blue, so 1-green, 2-red.
Upload with that, should show as Red Green Blue when you get it right.

@/example-rgb-revelation1pixel.description: For 1 pixel, helps you decode the right RGB code to use (e.g. GRB, etc), by lighting up 3 colors. Clone this node, and follow the instructions

B17Gy5NkN.content: How bright is light green? 30 seems not blinding, and less power

Bk-3D9VJV.content:
Use the debugger to watch the step go 0..pix-ct(-1),
and the ==0 detect it going around to zero,
and the clear firing

Byc819V1N.content:
If you are using more than 5 neopixels, you should use an external power supply for the neopixel strip.
The arduino/laptop-usb may brown out otherwise.
The brightness is set low in this example, so should actually allow more neopixels than 5, but an external power supply is the right thing to do.

H12khtVJN.content:
Set this to the number of pixels on the strip,
Or there will be a delay before the pattern repeats,
or only some of the pixels will be used.

H18j0NPi7N.content:
Hook up to get the RGB "order" right.
(see the example-rgb-revelation...'s)

H1DQjYE1E.content: "slowness" how long each step of the pattern takes

Hk9yRYEJN.content:
Generate the steps
Modulo makes it repeat from 0..pix-ct(-1)

HkBoAVPsQE.content: You chould use the actual hex value if you know it. e.g. for GRWB, etc.

HkIedcV1V.content: When the pattern restarts (step==0), clear the string.

Hkz4FK4yE.content:
This turns all pixels light green, one by one.
Repeat.
Based on the Adafruit Neopixel example "simple",
Adjust values below as necessary

HyFae54JN.content:
Do one pattern:
Light pixels one at a time.
step==0 signals start-again

SJnYecEkV.content:
The clock serves as "delay()".
Increase count every n seconds

SkI7_94y4.content: Tricky: switch the trigger to "clear" or on to "any"

Skio1jNyN.content: But, apparently you have to show too

r1lIl9EkN.content: Show the new color at each step.

rJ4TdFEyV.content: You should set this to the correct pin for the data-in

ryum9c4y4.content:
data-to-pulse
really a pulse for each step

r10N9J6vi.content: These "watch" nodes don't work for me anymore!

@/extract-rgb.description: Get red, green, blue elements of rgb color

@/gate(adafruitneopixel).description: Allows values to pass through only if EN pin is set to true

readme.content:
awgrover/adafruit-neopixel-ll
Arduino library for controlling single-wire-based LED pixels and strip.

Mechanically converted by https://forum.xod.io/u/awgrover using github.com:awgrover/arduino-2-xod from:
Adafruit NeoPixel (Adafruit_NeoPixel) by Adafruit. Version 1.1.7
https://github.com/adafruit/Adafruit_NeoPixel
